doc.title: Commodity crunch
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Hormel Foods Corp. Commodity crunchHormel Foods Corp. Commodity crunch_2025-08-29

passages.text: HRL reported very weak 3FQ results and 4FQ outlook is not pointing to any improvement in the near term. That said, certain underlying trends are encouraging and it is likely "just" a question of time to leave the commodity cost crunch behind. We stay Ow, but lower our PT to \(\) 34\(from\) \ \(36\)

Despite the significant sell- off on the day of earnings (HRL - 13.1% vs SPX +0.4%), coupled with a meaningful FY26 earnings revision of over 11% on adj. EPS, we keep our Ow rating unchanged. The second fiscal half clearly got off on the wrong foot for HRL. A sharp increase in commodity input costs, a continued soft consumer resulting in weaker foodservice momentum, and Planters profit growth lagging expectations made for the "perfect storm" to deliver underwhelming 3FQ results, and with most of the pressure continuing into 4FQ, the short- term outlook as well was more muted. With major protein input cost pressure accounting for a \(\sim\) 95mn COGS headwind (based on our calculations), adj. profits were impacted in an outsized manner. While, since peaking in July, we saw some of the input cost issues easing on a sequential basis, compared to 4FQ24 levels costs remain elevated. Given our downward earnings revision not only for FY25, but also for FY26, we slightly lower our PT to \(\) 34\(was\) \ \(36\) , but reiterate our Ow rating.

Weaker near- term outlook: Hormel cut profitability guidance for FY25 given significant increases in key input costs and a weaker consumer sentiment, now calling for adj. EPS of \(\) 1.43\(\) \ \(1.45\) (from \(\) 1.58 - \(\) 1.68). While the company is implementing strategic pricing actions to offset the continually high costs, a lag between price hikes and margin benefits is expected. As a result, Hormel feels its original internal growth goals for FY26 will not be realized - suggesting a weak start to FY26. While T&M savings would help partially offset these headwinds, we anticipate continued profit challenges in the near term as input costs remain elevated.

Results recap: Sales of just over \(\) 3bn\(were right above our estimate and up\) 5\% \(YoY, with better than expected volume growth in Retail and Foodservice. However, profits were a clear miss as each segment posted declines YoY, most notably in Retail and International. Most of the profit headwinds were driven by a\) \sim \$135mn jump in COGS due to higher input costs and increased volumes. As a result, segment profits on a reported basis were a 19% miss, and a 15% miss on an adjus tabasis. With in- line net interest expenses and taxes, bottom line adj. EPS of\) \ \(0.35\) was well below our outlook.
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 6. Completed: 28- Aug- 25, 20:51 GMT Released: 29- Aug- 25, 04:10 GMT Restricted - External

Source: Company data, Bloomberg, Barclays Research

**Profit guidance cut.** While HRL raised its sales estimate to $12.1-$12.2bn (from $12.0-$12.2bn)with organic sales growth of 2-3%, FY25 profits were lowered. Reported operating income was reduced to $980mn -$1bn (from $1.12-$1.19bn) with diluted EPS of $1.33-$1.35 (from $1.49-

\(\) 1.59\(), while adj. operating income and EPS were lowered to\) \ \(1.05 - \S 1.07bn\) (from \(\) 1.18- \(\) 1.25bn\) and \(\) 1.43- \ \(1.45\) (from \(\) 1.58- \ \(1.68\) ), respectively with a \(\) 0.02\(impact from tariffs. Tax rate expectations were lowered to\) - 22\% \(from\) 22- 23\% \(, capex is guided to\) 300mn \(the high end of the previous guidance), and T&M savings remain at\) 100- \ \(150mn\) (likely at the higher end).

For 4FQ25, HRL expects sales of \(\) 3.15- \ \(3.25bn\) with organic sales growth of \(1 - 4\%\) , diluted EPS of \(\) 0.36- \ \(0.38\) , and adj. EPS of \(\) 0.38- \ \(0.40\) . Profit recovery is expected to lag into next year.

While 2026 guidance was not provided, management stated that growth goals that had previously been set would not be realized, given changes in certain assumptions such as the input cost environment, stronger consumer sentiment, and earnings growth in 2FH25. Despite this, the company feels it is approaching the timeline for delivering long- term goals outlined at its previous investor day with organic net sales growth of \(2 - 3\%\) and operating income growth of \(5 - 7\%\) . Management will give a full FY26 outlook on the 4FQ25 earnings call.

Profits were impacted by input cost headwinds as pork bellies increased \(30\%\) YoY, pork cutouts jumped \(10\%\) , and pork trim grew \(20\%\) - far beyond the company's internal expectations. Combined with continued pressures in beef and nuts, the company faced 400bps of raw material cost inflation during 3FQ. Cost pressures are expected to carry into 4FQ as input prices have remained elevated. These 400bps reflect \(\sim 70\%\) of total COGS increase, or \(\) 95\$ mn.

To help offset input cost inflation HRL plans selective price increases during 4FQ and early 1FQ26, a second set of increases following higher pricing on the value- added Turkey business during 2FQ and 3FQ. Management notes that there is typically a lag between pricing increases and realized benefits, suggesting that improvements will not materialize until FY26.

HRL saw strong demand in turkey even after price increases implemented this year. Management noted that it delivered strong results on its value- added Turkey business - stating that its double- digit growth is outpacing the category in terms of branded growth, expanding market share - and have recovered profitability in 3FQ25. For 3Q, HRL sees broad- based top- line growth across the portfolio. Moreover, whole bird pricing benefits will be a fiscal 2026 story vs 2025 around Thanksgiving.

The Planters business now shows YoY growth in distribution, household penetration, and dollar sales as it laps the facility outage last year. Hormel expects continued sales momentum as capacity is now in place to fill demand. However, profitability improvements have been slower than anticipated due to poor mix and inflation costs.

Foodservice saw modest performance in the quarter despite industry- wide challenges. Organic volume and net sales growth outpaced broader industry trends, driven by the solutions- based portfolio and strength of its direct- selling organization. Planters Snack Nuts, Jennie- O Turkey, and Hormel Premium Pepperoni posted significant gains, with pepperoni alone achieving \(20\%\) YoY volume growth. However, margin compression persisted due to commodity inflation, particularly in pork and beef inputs. Looking ahead, Hormel expects profitability recovery to be gradual, supported by the pass- through nature of foodservice pricing and the continuation of healthy volumes. The company remains focused on leveraging its portfolio and sales capabilities to drive growth, even as broader industry traffic remains soft.

International growth is being led by China, supported by innovation, notably in meat & other snacking. Beyond China, export sales, especially for the Spam brand, added to top- line momentum, though profitability was negatively impacted by competitive pricing pressures in Brazil. Looking ahead, the company remains focused on expanding global brands and returning
the international segment to profitable growth through innovation and its proven in-country model.

**Transform & Modernize** savings finished in line with HRL's internal expectations and management believes full year savings will finish near the high end of the $100-$150mn range.Amid ~90 savings projects executed during 3FQ, HRL highlighted a partial closure of one facility and the reallocation of volumes across its production network.

**Inventories** **were** **up** **in** **3FQ** for Back to School (Skippy) and Center Store in 3FQ25, meaning that if market prices do decrease in 4FQ+, HRL will not see too much benefit. HRL affirmed that the rise in inventory was intentional, given its customer demand and needs to elevate its fill rates (center store). Higher input costs drove up some of this expansion.

**Capex** for the quarter totaled $72mn with a majority directed towards capacity enhancement and new technology initiatives. Additionally, HRL paid $159mn in dividends for the quarter with $474mn paid in the first 9 months of the fiscal year, and leverage remains in the target range of 1.5-2.0x.

While our sales forecast remains fairly unchanged, we lower our profit assumptions for FY25 and FY26. Specific to 4FQ, we lower our estimate to reflect ongoing input cost pressure resulting in an adj. EPS expectation of $0.39 (mid point of the 4FQ guidance of $0.38-$0.40). For next year,we see slightly higher sales, but a ~10% lower operating profit. These revision coupled with unchanged long-term margin assumptions result in a minor PT revision of ~6%.
FIGURE 1. HRL Change in Estimates Overview (in $mn, except EPS)
Source: Company Reports, Barclays Research estimates

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.
Valuation Methodology: We derive our \(34\) price target based on a DCF calculation assuming a WACC of \(7.1\%\) and a terminal growth rate of \(2.0\%\)

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Key downside risks: 1) higher commodity prices that could pressure Hormel's margins; 2) increased competition in Hormel's different product categories; 3) product recalls; 4) lawsuits and reputational concerns; 5) adverse FX conditions in HRL's foreign operations; and 6) consumer purchasing power risk.
